title: Understanding the Inverse Matrix
text: The inverse of a matrix is like the reciprocal of a number. When you multiply a matrix by its inverse, you get the identity matrix. For a 2x2 matrix, an inverse exists only when the determinant is not zero.

title: Formula for Finding Inverse
text: For a 2x2 matrix $$\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}$$, the inverse is given by $$1/(a*d-b*c)*(\begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{bmatrix})$$. This works as long as the determinant $$a d-b c$$ is not zero.

title: Calculating the Determinant
text: Let's calculate the determinant for the matrix $$\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{2} & \frac{3}{2} \\ 1 & \frac{-1}{2} \end{bmatrix}$$. Apply the formula $$a d-b c$$. What is the determinant?

title: Checking Determinant
text: Since the determinant is not zero, the matrix does have an inverse. Now, use the formula for the inverse of a matrix to find it.

title: Substitute into Inverse Formula
text: Using the inverse formula: $$1/(determinant)*(\begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{bmatrix})$$. Substitute the values from $$\begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{2} & \frac{3}{2} \\ 1 & \frac{-1}{2} \end{bmatrix}$$ and the calculated determinant. What is the inverse matrix?

title: Verification of Result
text: Great job! Remember, you can verify your result by checking if the original matrix times the inverse matrix gives the identity matrix $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$.
